definitions: reproduce the conditions or appearance of something artificially for training or testing purposes
create a computer model that represents the behavior of a real system or process
examples: The flight school uses machines to simulate flying conditions
Medical students simulate emergency procedures on mannequins before treating patients
Scientists simulate climate change using advanced computer models
The software can simulate traffic patterns in major cities

definitions: act in a way that violates moral or ethical principles
break divine or religious commandments through wrongful thoughts or actions
examples: Those who sin against others must seek forgiveness
He believed he had sinned by lying to his parents
Many religions teach that humans sin when they disobey God
The preacher warned the congregation not to sin through pride

definitions: produce musical sounds with the voice using melody and rhythm
perform songs professionally as an entertainer or artist
make a high-pitched whistling or ringing sound like certain objects
examples: The children sing happily during their music class
She loves to sing in the shower every morning
She sings opera at the Metropolitan Theater downtown
The band will sing their greatest hits tonight
The kettle sings when the water starts to boil
Bullets sang past their heads during the battle

definitions: burn the surface of something lightly causing minor damage or discoloration
expose to excessive heat causing surface damage without complete burning
examples: The iron was too hot and singed the delicate fabric
He accidentally singed his eyebrows while lighting the grill
The flames from the wildfire singed the tree branches
The hot pan singed the vegetables before they cooked properly

definitions: choose or identify one particular person or thing from a larger group
separate or isolate someone or something from others for special attention
examples: The teacher singled out the best essay for praise
The report singles several companies for their innovation
Security singled him out for additional screening at the airport
Critics singled the performance out as exceptional this season

definitions: go down below the surface of water or another liquid
move slowly downward through gravity or gradual settling
decrease in value, amount, quality, or strength over time
become fully understood or absorbed mentally after some time
examples: The ship began to sink after hitting the iceberg
Heavy stones sink quickly when thrown into the lake
The old house is sinking into the soft ground
She sank into the comfortable chair after work
Stock prices sank after the company announced poor earnings
His reputation sank after the scandal became public
The meaning of her words finally sank in later
Let the lesson sink in before moving to new material

definitions: drink something by taking small quantities into the mouth at a time
examples: She sipped her coffee slowly while reading the newspaper
The wine taster sips each sample before making notes
He sipped the hot soup carefully to avoid burning himself
Hummingbirds sip nectar from flowers throughout the day

definitions: draw liquid from one container to another through a tube using atmospheric pressure
illegally divert money or resources from their intended purpose for personal gain
examples: They siphoned gasoline from the truck into portable containers
The mechanic siphoned the old oil from the engine
The accountant siphoned funds from the company for years
Corrupt officials siphoned millions from the public treasury

definitions: be the male parent of an animal, especially a horse or dog
bring something into existence as an originator or creator
examples: The champion stallion has sired many winning racehorses
This bull sired over two hundred calves during his lifetime
The movement sired a new generation of political activists
His invention sired an entire industry of mobile devices

definitions: rest your weight on your buttocks with your back upright
serve as an official member of a committee, board, or jury
remain in one place unused or without being dealt with
be positioned or located in a particular place or position
examples: Please sit down and make yourself comfortable here
The cat sits by the window watching birds outside
She sits on the board of directors for three companies
The judge sits in the high court every weekday
The proposal has been sitting on his desk for months
Her car sits unused in the garage most days
The castle sits atop a hill overlooking the valley
The vase sits perfectly on the center of the table

definitions: place or build something in a particular position or location
choose and establish a strategic location for a facility or structure
examples: They decided to site the new hospital near the highway
The company will site its headquarters in the capital
Military commanders carefully site defensive positions on high ground
Engineers site bridges where the river is narrowest

definitions: place something in a particular position or location physically
place or consider something within a particular context or framework
examples: The architect situates the building to maximize natural light
They situate the memorial in the center of the park
We must situate this event within its historical context
The theory situates human behavior in evolutionary terms

definitions: determine or measure the dimensions or magnitude of something
treat fabric or paper with a substance to strengthen or stiffen it
examples: The tailor needs to size you for your custom suit
Workers size each piece of lumber before shipping
Bookbinders size the paper before applying gold leaf
Artists size their canvas to prepare it for painting

definitions: move along a surface on ice skates or roller skates
move quickly past or avoid dealing with something difficult
examples: Children love to skate on the frozen pond in winter
She skates gracefully across the ice during competitions
Politicians often skate around controversial questions during debates
He managed to skate through college without studying much

definitions: ride on a skateboard, performing movements and tricks on various surfaces
examples: Teenagers skateboard in the park every afternoon after school
He learned to skateboard when he was only six years old
Professional athletes skateboard in competitions for prize money
She skateboards to work instead of taking the bus

definitions: make a rough drawing showing the main features without detail
give a brief outline or general description of something
examples: The artist sketched the landscape quickly in her notebook
Students sketch the model during their art class
The CEO sketched out the company's five-year strategic plan
Let me sketch the basic concept before we discuss details

definitions: cause something to be asymmetrical or change from a straight line
present or influence something in a biased or distorted way
examples: The earthquake skewed the building's frame dangerously to one side
Wind pressure skews the bridge cables during storms
Media coverage can skew public opinion on important issues
The faulty sample skewed the research results significantly

definitions: travel over snow on skis for sport, recreation, or transportation
examples: They ski in the Alps every winter vacation together
She learned to ski when she was five years old
Professional athletes ski at speeds exceeding sixty miles per hour
Rescue teams ski to reach stranded hikers in mountains

definitions: slide sideways or forward in an uncontrolled way on a slippery surface
cause a vehicle or object to slide along a surface without rotating
examples: The car skidded on the icy road during the storm
Her bicycle skidded on the wet leaves around the corner
Workers skid heavy logs down the mountain using chains
They skid the boat across the sand into the water

definitions: remove a substance from the surface of a liquid
read something quickly to get the main points without details
move quickly and lightly along or near a surface
examples: She skims the fat from the soup before serving
Workers skim oil from the water after spills
Students often skim their textbooks the night before exams
I skimmed through the report to find the conclusions
Swallows skim across the lake catching insects at sunset
The stone skimmed across the water seven times

definitions: remove the skin or outer covering from an animal, fruit, or vegetable
scrape or graze the skin causing a surface injury
examples: Hunters skin the deer after a successful hunt
The chef skins tomatoes by blanching them first
He skinned his knee when he fell off his bike
Rock climbers often skin their hands on rough surfaces

definitions: move along with light springing steps alternating feet
deliberately leave out or pass over something in a sequence
deliberately not attend or participate in something scheduled
examples: Children skip happily down the path to the playground
She skips rope for exercise every morning
The reader skipped the boring chapters to reach the ending
Let's skip the formalities and get to business
He decided to skip class to go to the beach
Many people skip breakfast when running late for work

definitions: act as the captain or person in charge of a ship or boat
examples: He skippers luxury yachts for wealthy clients in the Caribbean
She has skippered fishing vessels for over twenty years
Who will skipper the team's boat in tomorrow's race?
The experienced sailor skippers charter boats during tourist season

definitions: engage in a brief and usually unplanned fight or conflict
examples: Border guards skirmished with smugglers near the crossing
The two armies skirmished before the main battle began
Political parties skirmish over policy details in the media
Protesters skirmished with police outside the government building

definitions: go around or past the edge of something rather than through it
avoid dealing with or discussing something difficult or controversial directly
examples: The hiking trail skirts the lake for several miles
We skirted the city to avoid heavy traffic
Politicians often skirt controversial issues during election campaigns
The report skirts the real problems facing the company

definitions: defeat an opponent thoroughly, especially by preventing them from scoring
examples: The home team skunked their rivals ten to zero
She skunked him at chess three games in a row
Our debate team skunked the competition at the tournament
The champion skunked all challengers without breaking a sweat

definitions: hit or kick a ball very high into the air in sports
examples: The golfer skied the ball over the green entirely
The kicker skied the field goal attempt in overtime
She accidentally skied her serve into the stands
The batter skied a pop fly to center field

definitions: engage in playful or mischievous behavior, especially in a carefree manner
examples: The children skylarked in the garden all afternoon long
Sailors used to skylark in the rigging during calm weather
Students were skylarking instead of studying for their exams
The young dolphins skylark near the boat entertaining tourists

definitions: communicate with someone using video calling technology over the internet
examples: She skypes her family every Sunday from abroad
Let's skype tomorrow morning to discuss the project
Remote workers skype into meetings from their home offices
Grandparents skype with their grandchildren every week

definitions: increase very quickly and suddenly to a much higher level
examples: Housing prices skyrocketed during the economic boom last year
The company's stock value skyrocketed after the announcement
Unemployment skyrocketed when the factories closed down permanently
Demand for the product skyrocketed following the viral video

definitions: become loose or less tight, or make something less taut
decrease effort or work less intensively than expected or required
examples: The rope slacked when he released the tension
Sailors slack the lines during calm weather conditions
Don't slack off just because the boss left early
Production workers tend to slack during the night shift

definitions: shut something forcefully and loudly, especially a door
criticize someone or something harshly and publicly
put, throw, or strike something with great force
examples: Don't slam the door when you leave the room
She slammed the book shut in frustration
Critics slammed the movie for its poor acting
The senator slammed his opponent's voting record
He slammed the ball into the net for the winning point
The wrestler slammed his opponent onto the mat

definitions: make false and damaging spoken statements about someone to harm their reputation
examples: The politician accused his opponent of slandering his character
She sued the newspaper for slandering her professional reputation
Gossipers often slander innocent people without considering the consequences
He was careful not to slander anyone during the interview

definitions: slope or cause to slope in a particular direction or angle
present information or a story from a particular biased perspective
examples: The roof slants downward to allow rain to run off
She slanted the picture frame to catch better light
The newspaper slants its coverage to favor conservative viewpoints
Don't slant the facts to support your argument

definitions: hit someone or something with the flat part of the hand
put or apply something quickly and carelessly
examples: She slapped him across the face for his rude comment
Waves slapped against the side of the boat
They slapped a coat of paint on the old fence
The company slapped a warning label on the product

definitions: cut something with a violent sweeping movement using a sharp object
reduce something dramatically in amount, size, or price
examples: The vandal slashed the painting with a knife
Thorns slashed his arms as he pushed through the bushes
The store slashed prices by fifty percent for the sale
The company slashed its workforce to cut costs

definitions: schedule or plan something for a particular time or purpose
criticize someone or something severely and publicly
examples: The movie is slated for release next summer
They slated the meeting for Tuesday afternoon
Critics slated the performance as the worst this season
The press slated the government's handling of the crisis

definitions: kill animals for food in a systematic and controlled way
kill people or animals in a cruel or violent way in large numbers
defeat an opponent completely and overwhelmingly in competition
examples: Farmers slaughter cattle at specific weights for market
The processing plant slaughters thousands of chickens daily
The invading army slaughtered innocent civilians in the village
Poachers illegally slaughter elephants for their ivory tusks
Our team slaughtered the opposition forty to seven
The chess master slaughtered every challenger at the tournament

definitions: work very hard for long hours under difficult conditions
examples: She slaved over the hot stove preparing dinner for twenty guests
Factory workers slaved in terrible conditions for minimal pay
Students slave away at their studies before final exams
He slaved for years to build his successful business

definitions: let saliva run from the mouth, especially showing desire or excitement
examples: The dog slavered while watching us eat dinner
The baby slavered all over his new toy
Fans slavered over the celebrity's latest Instagram post
Critics slavered at the chance to review the controversial film

definitions: kill someone or something in a violent or brutal way
greatly impress or amuse someone with a performance or action
examples: The knight vowed to slay the dragon threatening the kingdom
Ancient warriors would slay their enemies in battle
The comedian's jokes slay audiences every night
Her performance absolutely slayed at the talent show

definitions: ride or transport something on a sled over snow or ice
examples: Children love to sled down the hill after snowstorms
Mushers sled across Alaska during the famous Iditarod race
Workers sled supplies to remote research stations in Antarctica
The rescue team sledded the injured hiker to safety

definitions: hit or break something using overwhelming force like a sledgehammer
examples: Workers sledgehammered the concrete wall to demolish it
The boxer sledgehammered his opponent with powerful punches
Critics sledgehammered the new policy as completely ineffective
The storm sledgehammered the coastal towns with massive waves

definitions: rest in a state of unconsciousness with reduced brain activity
provide sleeping accommodation for a specified number of people
examples: Most adults need to sleep seven to nine hours nightly
The baby finally slept through the entire night
This cabin sleeps six people comfortably in three bedrooms
The yacht sleeps eight guests in luxury staterooms

definitions: fall as partly frozen rain or a mixture of rain and snow
examples: It started sleeting during the morning commute causing accidents
The weather forecast says it will sleet tomorrow afternoon
When temperatures hover near freezing, it often sleets instead of snowing
It sleeted throughout the night covering everything in ice

definitions: investigate or search for information carefully and persistently like a detective
examples: Journalists sleuthed for months to uncover the corruption scandal
She sleuthed through old records to find her ancestors
Amateur detectives sleuth online to solve cold cases
Researchers sleuthed through archives looking for lost manuscripts

definitions: turn or swing sharply or uncontrollably to one side
examples: The car slewed sideways on the icy road surface
The ship slewed to port in the strong winds
The crane slewed around to lift the heavy beam
His eyes slewed toward the unexpected noise

definitions: cut something into thin, flat pieces with a sharp implement
move easily and smoothly through something
examples: She sliced the bread into even pieces for sandwiches
The chef expertly sliced vegetables for the stir-fry
The boat sliced through the calm water effortlessly
The sword sliced through the air with a whistling sound

definitions: make hair or a surface smooth, glossy, and flat using water or oil
examples: He slicked his hair back with gel before the interview
Rain slicked the roads making driving dangerous
The mechanic slicked the parts with oil before assembly
She slicked her lips with gloss for the photo

definitions: move smoothly along a surface while maintaining continuous contact
gradually move into a worse condition or lower position
pass or move somewhere quietly, smoothly, or unnoticed
examples: Children slide down the playground equipment laughing joyfully
The skater slides gracefully across the ice
The company's profits continued to slide throughout the year
Standards have been sliding since the new management arrived
She slid the note under his door without knocking
He slid into the seat beside her quietly
